Award.AwardTitle: FIA-NP: Collaborative Research: Deployment-Driven Evaluation and Evolution of the eXpressive Internet Architecture

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The eXpressive Internet Architecture (XIA) project aims to design, evaluate, and realize a future network architecture that provides inherent trustworthiness, supports long-term evolution of network use models and network technology, and addresses adoption through careful design of APIs and reasoned analysis of interactions (or tussle points) between multiple stakeholders. XIA offers intrinsic security by offering each entity the ability to unilaterally validate that it is communicating with the correct counterparties. XIA admits new usage models to evolve through the use of flexible addresses. This architectural flexibility also exposes new features, for example, enabling users to trade-off maintaining anonymity against maximizing efficiency in content retrieval. To date, the XIA team has developed an initial architecture; built prototype implementations of the XIA data plane, network protocol stack, and secure unicast communication using Scalability, Control and Isolation On next-generation Networks (SCION); engaged in a wide range of basic networking and security research; and investigated questions raised by future Internet architecture research.

In the next phase of research on XIA, principal investigators (PIs) advance the original vision of XIA by deepening the ongoing research thrusts, driven in part by research questions exposed during the initial investigation. The research agenda also includes an increased emphasis on control protocols based on a unified control plane architecture. The research will be driven through two network deployments that challenge the architectural framework: a vehicular network deployment in the city of Pittsburgh, and a video delivery environment spanning the U.S. These deployments also leverage and deepen the work on secure network operations, including providing a highly available infrastructure and secure authentication mechanisms. Finally, these deployments necessitate further research on building a robust XIA network, and establish best practices for using the XIA architecture, including support for mobility and a rich session layer. The research will continue to be informed by issues of deployability and economic viability, and to consider XIA as perceived by end users. The plan therefore includes research on governance, economic implications of high availability, and user studies that investigate the interplay between privacy, transparency and user control. Finally, the PIs will develop methods for performing a comparative evaluation of future Internet architectures. This evaluation methodology includes a definition of evaluation criteria, a discussion of the importance of direct and indirect evaluation, and evaluation using the XIA network environments and other use cases.

Intellectual Merit: The intellectual merit of the proposed work is an ambitious study of the effectiveness of a new architectural framework, evaluated in the context of two challenging network environments. The cross-cutting expertise of the team enables broad and deep investigation, starting from specification and implementation of many key network and security building blocks, up to application-specific methods delivering innovative solutions in the vehicular and video delivery environments. The evaluation spans multiple disciplines, ranging from low-level performance evaluation to reasoning about incentive-compatibility and economic benefits of the PIs' approach to a quantification of user experience.

Broader Impacts: The project will establish a framework for evaluating network architectures that will be broadly applicable to FIA research. The PIs propose a variety of education and outreach activities to accompany the proposed research. Educational activities include new courses on clean-slate network design, and teaching and internship activities for under-represented and high school students. Broader outreach activity also includes a plan to involve and inform policymakers on the health of the current and future Internet led by a PI who formerly served at the FCC.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The eXpressive Internet Architecture (XIA) project aims to design, evaluate, and realize a future network architecture that provides inherent trustworthiness, supports long-term evolution of network use models and network technology, and addresses adoption through careful design of APIs and reasoned analy- sis of interactions (or “tussle” points) between multiple stakeholders. XIA offers intrinsic security by offering each entity the ability to unilaterally validate that it is communicating with the correct counterparties. XIA admits new usage models to evolve through the use of flexible addresses that allow users to expressively spec- ify their intent, including “new” types of user intent, and backwards-compatible fallback pathways to satisfy their intent. This architectural flexibility also exposes new features, for example, enabling users to trade-off maintaining anonymity against maximizing efficiency in content retrieval, and allowing ISPs more control over path selection in inter-domain routing. In the first phase of XIA, the XIA team has developed an initial architecture; built prototype implementations of the XIA router data plane, network protocol stack, and secure unicast communication using SCION; engaged in a wide range of basic networking and security research; and investigated questions raised by future Internet architecture research that arise in the fields of network economics, public policy, and human-computer interaction.

In the second phase of research on XIA, the team advanced the original vision of XIA by deepening the ongoing research thrusts, driven in part by research questions exposed during our initial investigation. The team placed an increased emphasis on control protocols based on a unified control plane architecture. The research was driven through two network deployments that challenge the XIA architectural framework: a vehicular network deployment in the city of Pittsburgh, and a video delivery environment spanning the U.S. These deployments helped refine the control plane architecture, leading to the development of a new evolvable control plane, and integrate it with the secure data plane. These deployments also leveraged and enabled the team to deepen our work on secure network operations, including providing a highly available infrastructure and secure authentication mechanisms. Finally, these deployments lead to further research on building a robust XIA network, and establish best practices for using the XIA architecture, including support for mobility and a rich session layer.

The research was informed by issues of deployability and economic viability, and to consider XIA as perceived by end users. The research program therefore included work on governance, the economic implications of high availability, and user studies that investigate the interplay between privacy, transparency and user control. 

The intellectual merit of the proposed work is an ambitious study of the effectiveness of a new architectural framework, evaluated in part in the context of two challenging network environments. The XIA team explored specification and implementation of many key network and security building blocks, up to application-specific methods delivering innovative solutions in our proposed vehicular and video delivery environments. The team's evaluation of the proposed architecture spanned multiple disciplines, ranging from low-level performance evaluation to reasoning about incentive-compatibility and economic benefits of our approach to a quantification of user experience.

On the broader impact front, the proposed work resulted in a working prototype of an inherently secure and trustworthy network that can flexibly evolve over time to support diverse usage models and technologies, a rich set of interesting applications running atop the network, deployment across two important network environments, and a community of users developing atop the prototype. Furthermore, the project established a framework for evaluating network architectures that will be broadly applicable to FIA research. The project involved a variety of education and outreach activities including new courses on clean-slate network design, and teaching and internship activities for under-represented and high school students.
